Title: Some of what we did at Danger: The future that everyone forgot

Author: k-mcgrady
Content:
>> "but most people don't use their real name (or a proper name at all) on twitter"

They might not use it as their username but most people have their name in their twitter profile. (e.g. when you view a profile on twitter it has picture, first name last name, @username). Maybe they were able to check the first/last name and not just the username.

Author: amjd
Content:
They don't own those numbers. The calls just 'appear' to come from a number like +XXXXX, where XXXXX is the random verification number. If you have used any voip service you'll know how trivial it is to make calls appear to come from just about any number.

According to the website they support 150+ countries so you could go ahead and give it a try from their demo page.

Edit: Here's the link to their demo page: http://motp.in/SampleCode.html"

Author: dangrossman
Content: I think you're exaggerating a bit. Stripe has "thousands of customers". There are tens of millions of businesses accepting credit cards. PayPal has 230 million active accounts. First Data has 6.2 million merchants. Stripe isn't the Amazon of anything yet.

Author: semenko
Content:
Sadly, it kind-of is. Some sites do strange things and present /entirely different content/ over HTTPS.

Best example: http://www.forbes.com/ versus https://www.forbes.com/

(HTTPS Everywhere semi-infrequently hits those bugs.)"

Author: jamesaguilar
Content: Once upon a time polio was not just incurable but not even conceivably curable. I can't help my feeling that when people say we will never crack cancer, they are only revealing a lack of imagination and historical perspective.

Author: tesseractive
Content:
There are no boys who grow up worrying that only girls go into tech and that it's not for them. Female role models are not problematic for boys because everyone knows that men will be welcome. This situation is not symmetric across gender.

Are there girls whose role models are male and are fine with that? Of course. But it is difficult to determine how big a role the lack of more female role models may play in discouraging other girls who never go into the field, and the idea that more same-gender rule models may be beneficial is, at the very least, a reasonable hypothesis.

Author: robotresearcher
Content:
> very tiny robots with very specific targeting patterns can eradicate cancerous cells.

This is happening already, but the robots are not electromechanical, but engineered protein-munging machines adapted from or delivered by modified viruses. At the size scale required, regular robots are way too clunky.
